resources.string: Launch \"Explore by touch\" tutorial
Accessibility tutorial
Next
Previous
Finish
Exit
Touch disabled while tutorial is speaking
Lesson 1: Exploring the screen

When Explore by Touch is turned on, you can touch the screen to learn what\â€™s under your finger. For example, the current screen contains app icons. Find one of them by touching the screen and sliding your finger around.
Good. Keep sliding your finger around the screen until you find at least one more icon.
You can also explore by swiping your finger left and right anywhere on the screen. Try quickly swiping from left to right to move to the next icon.
To activate something that you\'ve explored, tap the screen twice. Explore until you find the %1$s icon. Then double-tap anywhere on the screen to activate it.
You found the %1$s icon. Double-tap anywhere on the screen to activate the icon.
You explored past the %1$s icon. Try exploring the screen until you find the %1$s icon again.
To move to the next lesson, find the %1$s button, located near the bottom-right corner of the screen, then double-tap to activate it.
Lesson 2: Scrolling through lists

To scroll through a list, you can slide two fingers along the screen. For example, the current screen contains a list of app names that can scroll up or down. First, try to explore the screen and identify an app.
Now place two fingers on an item in the list and slide both fingers up. If you reach the top of the screen, lift your fingers, place them lower on the list, and continue sliding up.
Explore the screen to find one more app.
You can also scroll an entire page by swiping your finger. To scroll to the next page, swipe right then left using a single motion. Try to scroll to the next page by swiping right then left.
Explore the screen again to find an app in the current page.
Swiping the opposite direction, left then right in a single motion, will move to the previous page. Try to scroll to the previous page by swiping left then right.
To move to the next lesson, find the %1$s button, located near the bottom-right corner of the screen, then double-tap to activate it.
Lesson 3: Context menus

TalkBack has two context menus that make it easy to find settings and controls, the Global Context Menu and the Local Context Menu. You can activate a menu item by sliding your finger around the circle of menu items and releasing when you hear the desired item. Try bringing up the Global Context Menu by swiping your finger %1$s in a single motion.

The Global Context Menu contains general commands that work everywhere throughout TalkBack. Try reading all the text on the screen. Press on the center of the screen to bring up a circular menu around your finger, and then slide your finger around the circle of options until you hear \"%1$s.\"
You closed the Global Context Menu. Try bringing up the Global Context Menu again by swiping your finger %1$s in a single motion.

Good. That command will read all of the items on the screen. In addition to a Global Context Menu, TalkBack also has a Local Context Menu. The Local Context Menu contains controls that change based on what item on the screen you have selected. Try bringing up the Local Context Menu by swiping your finger %1$s in a single motion.
Pressing your finger down in the center of the screen and then lifting it will cancel and close the menu. Try closing the Local Context Menu now.

You now know how to bring up and navigate through the context menus. You will learn more about when to use the context menus in the following lesson. Find and activate the %1$s button near the bottom-right corner of the screen to continue.
Lesson 4: Reading granularities

TalkBack has granularity controls that give you different ways to navigate through text. For example, you can read text paragraph by paragraph, word by word, or even character by character. To get started, find the text box in the center of the screen to read its content.

Focusing an item will read all of its text using the default granularity. Try changing the granularity to read this text one character at a time. This can be helpful if you want to spell a name or read an email address, for example. First, swipe your finger %1$s to bring up the Local Context Menu.
You navigated away from the target text box. Try tapping on the center of the screen to navigate back to the text box.
Good. Now, slide your finger around the menu until you hear %1$s, then select it.
You closed the Local Context Menu without changing to %1$s. Swipe your finger %2$s to bring up the Local Context Menu again.

Good. You are now navigating by character granularity. Swiping from the top of the screen to the bottom of the screen will move forward by one character. Try swiping from the top of the screen to the bottom of the screen 3 times to read the next 3 characters of the text.
You changed the granularity so that it is no longer %1$s. You can change back to %1$s from the Local Context Menu by swiping your finger %2$s in a single motion.
You now know how to change the reading granularity and read text. To continue, activate the %1$s button, located near the bottom-right corner of the screen.

You now know how to change the reading granularity and read text. This concludes the TalkBack tutorial. To exit the tutorial, find and activate the %1$s button, located near the bottom-right corner of the screen.
This is some example text that you can read at different granularities.
Lesson 5: Editing text
This lesson will help you use TalkBack to edit a piece of text. To get started, find the text box in the center of the screen.
Once you have selected a text field that can be edited, you can tap twice anywhere on the screen to bring up the keyboard and start editing the text. Try double-tapping the screen now.
There is already some text in the field. You can move the cursor to the beginning of the text from the local context menu. Swipe %1$s in a single motion, activate %2$s, then activate %3$s.
When editing text, it is helpful to choose an appropriate granularity from the local context menu. Swipe %1$s in a single motion, activate %2$s, then activate %3$s.
Good. Now, swipe your finger from top to bottom to navigate through the text one word at a time. Continue swiping from top to bottom until you reach the end of the text.

When you are editing text, you can also use the volume keys on your device to navigate through the text instead of swiping your finger. TalkBack also gives you controls for selecting text. You can select all the text in the box using the local context menu. Swipe %1$s in a single motion, activate %2$s, then activate %3$s.

Good. You selected all the text. If you want finer control over what you have selected, you can activate selection mode from the local context menu. When you are editing text, you can type using the on-screen keyboard by sliding your finger around the keyboard and lifting when you hear the desired key. Try typing some text to replace the text you selected.

When you are finished editing the text, you can close the keyboard. Slide your finger until you find the Done button, then lift your finger to activate it. This concludes the TalkBack tutorial. To exit the tutorial, find and activate the %1$s button, located near the bottom-right corner of the screen.
Sample text
Exit
Explore by Touch Required
This tutorial requires Explore by touch. Please turn TalkBack on and enable Explore by touch before launching the tutorial.
TalkBack Suspended
The TalkBack tutorial is not available while feedback is paused. Please resume TalkBack feedback and relaunch the tutorial to continue.
Missing gesture assignment
There is no gesture assigned to the \"%1$s\" action. Please visit TalkBack Settings to set a shortcut gesture for that action, and then relaunch the TalkBack tutorial.
